summary: Martin Luther King, Jr. is mentioned in several CIA documents, primarily in the context of the aftermath of his assassination and investigations into potential subversive influences within the civil rights movement. The documents include a summary of Cuban media coverage of his death, indicating interest in international reactions. There's also mention of the House Select Committee on Assassinations' (HSCA) investigation into his assassination alongside President Kennedy's, focusing on potential leads related to James Earl Ray. Furthermore, there are documents discussing efforts to gather intelligence on Communist, Castroist, and radical influences within the civil rights movement following King's death, suggesting concerns about exploitation of the situation. Other documents mention individuals connected to civil rights activities and their interactions with international organizations and figures.
significance: While not directly related to the JFK assassination, Martin Luther King's assassination is mentioned in the context of the House Select Committee on Assassinations' (HSCA) investigation of both assassinations. The documents also reveal concerns about foreign exploitation of the civil rights movement following King's death, indicating a broader interest in potential subversive influences.
